message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injury mechanism, antalgic gait, and backward translation of the foreleg suggest a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury. The PCL prevents backward translation of the tibia on the femur. An anterior cruciate ligament injury would result in instability in all directions. A lateral collateral ligament injury would not cause posterior instability, and a lateral meniscus injury would not cause backward translation of the tibia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible injury to the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). The PCL prevents the tibia from moving backwards in relation to the femur and its injury can cause posterior sag of the tibia. The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is typically injured when the knee is rotated or twisted, while the lateral collateral ligament (LCL) is injured when there is a force on the inside of the knee. The lateral meniscus is often injured with twisting movements and would not cause posterior sag of the tibia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation suggests posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury, which is often caused by a direct blow to the flexed knee or a fall onto a bent knee. The backward translation of the foreleg during the examination is a key feature of PCL injury. Anterior cruciate ligament injury would result in a positive Lachman test or pivot shift test, while lateral collateral ligament injury would result in instability on varus stress testing. Lateral meniscus injury would likely present with pain on lateral joint line palpation and a positive McMurray test.

The patient has a positive posterior draw test, indicating that the PCL is likely injured. The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) stabilizes the knee against anterior tibial translation and is less likely to be injured in this scenario. Lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injury would result in varus instability. Lateral meniscus injury would result in pain and clicking in the lateral joint line, but would not cause posterior instability.
